questions.question: A 14-year-old girl presents with a flare-up of her atopic dermatitis which was previously well-controlled. Examination reveals erythematous lesions over the neck. Which of the following is the initial management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A. Topical steroids Explanation: The patient presents with a mild flare of AD for which the initial management is topical steroids (ointment if lichenified; cream if scaly/oozy) along with emollients. Management of atopic dermatitis includes Controlling environmental factors like removing triggers(ex dust), avoiding extreme temperatures, detergents, and harsh soaps. Restoring the compromised barrier: Hydration using emollients and moisturizers) Emollients soften the skin, reduce itch, and enhance the effect of topical corticosteroids. Persistent use of emollients when the inflammation is in remission may reduce the time and frequency of flare-ups. Pharmacological treatment:- Localized condition: Topical corticosteroids +/- antihistamines +/- antibiotics For face: Calcineurin inhibitors (pimecrolimus and tacrolimus) Severe disease (systemic management): Oral corticosteroids, cyclosporine, and azathioprine. Newer drugs : Crisabole: PDE-4 inhibitor (topical). Dupilumab: IL-4 receptor alpha antagonist (systemic). Tofacitinib: JAK kinase inhibitors Apremilast: PDE-4 inhibitor (also used in psoriasis) Atopic eczema treatment algorithm: TCI- topical calcineurin inhibitors; TCS, topical corticosteroids.

questions.question: A 12-year-old girl presents with multiple hypopigmented patches, as shown below. She reports a prior history of asthma. Examination reveals lesions over her face as shown below. There is mild scaling over the lesions. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: likely has pityriasis alba (PA). Pityriasis alba is a benign condition that predominantly affects children and adolescents and is associated with atopic asthma. The classical presentation is multiple hypopigmented, scaly, round, or oval macules and patches, predominantly over the face, upper trunk, and upper limbs. These may be associated with mild erythema or scaling. On Wood's lamp examination, lesions are nonfluorescent. It is a self-limited condition, treatment options include emollients, low-potency topical corticosteroids, and topical calcineurin inhibitors. Incorrect explanations: Option A: Tinea versicolor: It is caused by Malasezzia species and is more common in the truncal region. It presents with hypo or hyperpigmentation in patients with oily and sweaty skin and fine scales on scratching. There may be mild pruritus and erythema with yellow to green fluorescence on Wood’s lamp . The KOH mount shows a spaghetti and meatball appearance. Treatment includes antifungal agents like topical selenium sulfide and topical ketoconazole. KOH mount: Wood's lamp: Option B: Indeterminate leprosy lacks scales on examination. Indeterminate Hansen presents with a single lesion. Option C: Vitiligo presents with depigmented milky white patches without scaling.

questions.question: A 55-year-old female presents with multiple red, scaly patches with greasy, yellow scales in her hair. Which of the following represents an appropriate treatment option for her?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A. Azole-based shampoo Explanation: The given case scenario describes seborrheic dermatitis (SD) , an inflammatory response to colonization by the Malassezia fungal species. In adults and adolescents, it is characterized by yellow, greasy scales involving the face, scalp (dandruff), nasolabial folds, and retro auricular region due to the major activity of sebaceous glands here leading to increased sebum production. It is also seen in infants < 3 months old due to presence of maternal androgens. Involvement of the scalp and face leads to a characteristic finding called cradle cap. It is also called infantile seborrheic dermatitis. Management includes stopping Malassezia growth using antifungals like Topical creams: Azoles (Sertaconazole, Propiconazole, Luliconazole) · Azole, zinc pyrithione (ZPTO), ciclopirox olamine, and selenium sulfide-based shampoo Topical corticosteroids or Topical calcineurin inhibitors + Shampoo or Azoles for dry erythema Antihistamines for itching Oral antifungals (itraconazole, fluconazole) for severe and unresponsive disease No oil application, as sebaceous

questions.question: Which of the following examination findings would not be expected in acute eczema?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B. Lichenification Explanation: The given clinical scenario likely describes acute eczema that does not show lichenification, which is a feature of chronic eczema. Eczema or atopic dermatitis is a chronic, pruritic, inflammatory condition of the skin. The pattern of the rash varies with age Infantile phase (<2 years): The lesions are present on the face and extensor aspect of the knees and elbows consisting of erythema and discrete or confluent oedematous papules. The papules may become exudative and crusted. Childhood phase (2 years to puberty): Presents as erythema, crusting, excoriation, hyper and hypopigmentation, and warty lichenification involving the elbow and knee flexures. Adult phase : Similar to the childhood phase with more localized and lichenified lesions. Based on the duration of complaints, eczema may be acute, subacute, or chronic. Acute eczema presents with itching and dryness of the skin. Examination findings include signs of inflammation - erythema, oedema, vesicles, oozing, and crusting. Chronic eczema results from long-term untreated or inadequately treated eczema. Exam findings include lichenification, increased skin markings, hyperpigmentation, and thickening of the skin as shown below. Subacute eczema lies in between acute and chronic eczema - erythema and scaling may be seen.

questions.question: A 35-year-old housewife presents with itchy and burning lesions over her hands. She reports using a new detergent solution at home and lesions developed within few hours of usage. She has not had similar complaints in the past. Which of the following statements is correct regarding her diagnosis?

options.A: Occurs due to type IV hypersensitivity
options.B: Lesions may spread beyond the site of contact
options.D: Depends on intensity, duration and concentration of substance

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Depends on intensity, duration and concentration of substance Explanation: This patient presents with: Acute onset of itchy and burning lesions Confined to the area of contact (hands) After exposure to a new detergent No prior sensitisation history These features are most consistent with Irritant Contact Dermatitis (ICD) . ICD depends on: Intensity of the irritant (e.g., detergent chemicals) Duration of contact Concentration of the substance used Irritant contact dermatitis Allergic contact dermatitis Onset Within minutes to hours of exposure Sensitization with first exposure, lesions with subsequent exposure - may be days/ weeks later Pathogenesis Direct disruption of the epidermal barrier, inflammation, and cellular immunity activation. Type IV hypersensitivity Predisposition No genetic predisposition Genetic/ family predisposition present Distribution Site of contact May extend beyond the site of contact Causes Detergents, Alkalis, cement, Acids, Cutting oils, Organic solvents Nickel (watches), PPD - paraphenyl diamine(hair dye), topical neomycin, Parthenium plants Occurs due to type IV hypersensitivity (Option A): This is true for allergic contact dermatitis , not irritant type. Lesions may spread beyond the site of contact (Option B): Again, a feature of allergic contact dermatitis , not ICD. Diagnosed by a patch test (Option C): Patch testing is used to diagnose allergic contact dermatitis , not ICD.

questions.question: A 29-year-old woman presents with an intensely pruritic, red rash over her neck as shown in the image. What is the most likely causative substance?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Nickel Explanation: This patient presents with ACD over the neck, likely due to a new artificial jewelry . Artificial jewellery typically contains nickel , which can cause ACD. Other sites of ACD due to Nickel include wrists (watches) and waist (belt buckle). Other causative substances of ACD include: Allergens Sources Nickel, cobalt Artificial jewellery, jean buttons, wristwatches Chromium Cement, paintings Potassium dichromate Leather, detergents Epoxy resins, phenols Plastics Parthenium Parthenium plants - airborne ACD Propylene glycol Cosmetics, Medicaments Paraphenyl diamine(PPD) Hair dyes Neomycin, gentamycin Topical medications Latex/rubber Gloves, shoes, belts Para Tertiary Butyl Phenol (PTBP) Bindi IIII Allergic contact dermatitis on forehead: Allergic contact dermatitis due to hair dye:

questions.question: Interpret the following result of the photopatch test. Reaction on the non-irradiated side: Positive Reaction on the irradiated side: Negative
questions.explanation: test on the non-irradiated side is allergic, while a negative reaction on the irradiated side indicates no photo allergy. A photo patch test is a diagnostic procedure that combines patch testing with UV irradiation. Antigen patches are applied in duplicate, with one patch covered with opaque material. The Patient is called back after 48 hours, and the patches are irradiated with UVA light (5 J/cm²). Exposing the patches to UV light simulates real-life conditions where the skin is exposed to sunlight. It is mainly used for Photoallergic dermatitis. Interpretation of photo patch test in photoallergic dermatitis Reaction on non-irradiated side Reaction on the irradiated side Interpretation Positive Negative Allergy, no photo allergy Positive Positive Allergy, with photo exaggeration Negative Positive Pure photo allergy Negative Negative No allergy, no photo allergy

questions.question: What is the best time to visualize the results of the patch test?
questions.explanation: hours. Patch tests are usually used to detect contact allergy of the delayed hypersensitivity type. They are usually read at 48–72 h, 96 h and again after 1 week, but can also be read at 15–30 min to detect contact urticaria. If only one patch test reading is possible, a day 4 reading has been recommended. Indications for patch testing Allergic contact dermatitis Eczematous disorders failing to respond to treatment (including occupational) The back is the most commonly used site. Before testing, the site should be free of eczema. Finn chambers or discs are used to ensure the allergen contacts the skin. The discs are applied and removed after 48 hours. A typical regimen is a 48 h application time, with readings taken 1 h after removal and again 48 h later (that is day 2 and day 4). A single day 2 reading is not advised as it may lead to the labelling of some marginal irritants as allergens and positive reactions to more poorly absorbed allergens may be missed. If only one patch test reading is possible, a day 4 reading has been recommended. The positive result might include erythema, papule, pustule, and vesicles at the site of application. It might also lead to thickening of the dermis.

questions.question: A 45 year old gardener presents to the clinic with a persistent itchy rash on his exposed skin areas, including the face, neck, and arms. On examination, there are erythematous, scaly plaques with some vesicles and lichenification shown below. He mentions that he often works near a patch of wild plants that have small white flowers. Which of the following is the causative agent?
questions.explanation: chronic airborne contact dermatitis. Given his occupation as a farmer, this is likely phytophotodermatitis (PPD)

questions.question: A 10-year-old boy has been recently diagnosed with atopic dermatitis(AD). Which of the following is not a minor feature of AD?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D. Red dermatographism Explanation: Among the given options, red dermatographism is not considered a minor feature of atopic dermatitis (AD). It describes the presence of red streaks on the skin upon stroking as shown below and is commonly associated with urticaria. White dermatographism refers to a white line on the stroking of the skin due to vasoconstriction as seen in AD. Black dermatographism is due to metal deposition in the skin surface, as shown below. Minor features of AD include: Eye: Periorbital dermatitis Hertoghe’s sign - lateral madarosis due to continuous rubbing Dennie Morgan fold - extra infraorbital fold of skin Allergic shiners Papillary conjunctivitis Anterior subcapsular cataract Keratoconus Skin: Cheilitis & perioral dermatitis - lip inflammation surrounded by area of pallor, and perioral dermatitis (headlight sign) Ichthyosis (dry skin) Keratosis pilaris - due to occluded hair follicles, with coiled hair White dermatographism - white line on stroking of skin due to vasoconstriction Hyperlinear palms and soles

questions.question: An elderly male who works as a security guard presents with a chronic rash over his legs. Examination reveals a hyperpigmented rash with scaling over the medial aspect of both ankles, as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: the medial side of the ankle and a risk factor of venous stasis (standing-security guard) most likely has varicose eczema(VE) / venous stasis dermatitis. It is typically seen in patients with long-standing varicose veins/ venous insufficiency. Risk factors include a family history of venous disease, standing occupations (security guard), obesity, female sex, and prior deep vein thrombosis. Chronic pooling of blood/ venous hypertension leads to circulatory changes in the dermis including dilated capillaries and increased permeability that lead to pericapillary fibrin cuffs, oedema, leucocyte accumulation, and hemosiderin deposits. VE is characterized by erythematous, scaling patches/ plaques over a background of chronic oedema. The medial ankle is most commonly involved, and the changes may extend up to the knee. With time, due to pruritus, there may be lichenification, scaling, and even ulceration. Varicose ulcer most commonly involves gaiter area[lower 1/3rd of leg ] Incorrect options explanation: A. Dyshidrotic eczema ( aka Pompholyx) : This is a condition associated with atopic dermatitis that presents with vesicles over the palms and fingers (classically on sides of fingers). C. Nummular eczema: This is a type of endogenous eczema characterised by sharply defined, round or coin-shaped, erythematous, and eczematous plaques. It commonly involves lower extremities. Pruritus is common, and lesions may ooze fluid. D. Asteatotic eczema: This is seen in the elderly and occurs due to decrease of lipid coating granules in epidermis. It may be more prominent in dry seasons (winter). It is characterized by cracked, dry skin called cracked porcelain or crazy

questions.question: A 57-year-old male presents to you with an extensive erythematous rash that covers >90% of his body surface, as shown below. He is a known case of pemphigus foliaceous, requiring regular immunosuppressants but not adhering to medications. The skin is warm and tender to the touch. Which of the following is not a potential complication of his condition?
questions.explanation: inadequate treatment of his pemphigus, which can lead to high output heart failure and not heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. Erythroderma, or exfoliative dermatitis, is a severe complication of other underlying diseases.
